page.title: 03Hall Farm/Economics/Blaby.
page.content: The farm income is derived from its milk sale,and from calves.The cut in E.E.C. milk quotas means a loss of income and will inevitably mean that economies in feed and fertilizer will have to be made. {Milk:}Annual yield per cow 6500 litres Average winter price 15p a litre Average summer price 12p a litre {Dairy Cow:} Average value Â£500. {Cattle food: }Average price/ton Â£145 {Fertilizer :} Average price per ton Â£135.Quantity used per acre per yr. 9 to 10 cwt. {Machinery:}Three tractors and a range of ploughs etc.but no combine. Milking parlour.8 cows,4 being milked. {Crop yield: }Silage=450 tons per year. 7 or 8 tons per acre from one cut,a total of 10 tons including production from a late second cut.{Hay}and { {Barley }both yield about 2tons an acre
